The government is paying private lenders over $8 billion a year in subsidies right now.

secretary of education and one of the Republican leaders in Congress who oppose direct lending.
If the Obama administration really wants to give students a break, though, Alexander says, why not use those savings to cut the interest rate on student loans?

This is going to cost the students about $1,700 to $1,800 in higher interest payments over 10 years on an average $25,000 loan.

Proponents of direct lending say Alexander's figures and his argument are misleading; interest rates are not going up.
Under direct lending, students won't pay more than the fixed rate set by Congress 6.8 percent.
